posts.name: Austin Muse
posts.cooked: Our team purchased a Limelight 3 in the fall and are eager to implement vision this season. We are running swerve drive. Everyone says how easy it is to use the limelight camera but none of the documentation makes any sense and is vague at best. Could anyone point me to an example that is easy to understand for complete newbies on how to use the camera to see any Apriltag on the reef and the driver hit a button to automatically drive to a specific place to score on the reef. Optimally we want a button to align to the left branch and another button to align to the right branch.

posts.name: icemannie
posts.cooked:
1. You can accurately and quickly aim your robot using only a limelight and your drivetrain.

Limelight also has a POI - point of interest feature that lets you offset the tag center to either side. Download LimelightHelperfrom LimelightHelpers

Also search Chief Delphi for information- it’s a big topic this year,

link_counts.title: Aiming With Visual Servoing | Limelight Documentation

posts.name: Austin Muse
posts.cooked: I have seen this example already and it is still quite vague. We need someone to explain it in a way that you don’t need degree in computer science to understand how to do it. Seems like there is quite a bit of gatekeep by more elite teams behind implementing Vision effectively.

posts.name: Ryan Swanson
posts.cooked: This attitude isn’t going to win you a lot of support. The CD community is a very helpful resource. The Limelight support team is fantastic. Ask nicely and you will find the help you need.

posts.name: Austin Muse
posts.cooked: I thought I did ask nicely.

link_counts.title: Integrating Limelight into our Yagsl code

posts.name: Pat Mattin
posts.cooked:
Truffle_Shuffle:

Seems like there is quite a bit of gatekeep by more elite teams behind implementing Vision effectively.

Not really sure what you mean by this. There’s no conspiracy of “elite teams” making implementation of vision harder. I’d say 6328 is near the top as far as vision goes, and they provide a lot of resources to other teams.

The linked example and LL docs aren’t perfect, but it’s about as simple as you’re going to get. Vision isn’t easy, especially when you’re trying to integrate with translational movement.

(For context, we’ve been working on it all season and are only now at a point where we can auto align)

posts.name: 4391 Programming Mentor
posts.cooked: I’m also often intimidated by all the big words and methods people can sometimes use on here and at the same time call it simple.  So I get it.  Our team took on the vision stuff a couple years ago as “a journey”.  We’re now pretty darn good with it.  We started by just getting one on there and looking at all the data coming out of it and absorbed all that.  That first year we struggled hard but finally got our robot to drive “tag relative” and we got pretty dangerous.  Then we decided to use the tags to help keep track of where we are on the field (pose estimation) and then make auto-drive routines to go to known coordinates on the field.  It took us 2 years (we don’t meet off season) to get good at it.  Maybe others can do it somehow right out of the box, but we sure the heck couldn’t, so you’re not alone.  I think you might want to lower your immediate goals and just start by looking at the data and thinking of the field as a big grid and things will start to take shape.  Probably not what you wanted to hear but just know you’re not alone with the frustration.  It’s hard for most.  I think you need to consider it a journey that might take a couple seasons.

posts.name: Austin Muse
posts.cooked: I think we have a very realistic goal. We want to have a button that aligns the robot either 6 inches to left of the AprilTag on the reef with one button or 6 inches to the right on another button. I know what “pose estimation” is, we aren’t trying all that, I just can’t find an example of how to do what I am asking and no one can explain to me how to do it. That is why I am frustrated. We have been trying to figure this out since last year and we aren’t any closer because whenever I come on here and ask, no one can give me a straightforward answer and I have no idea what I am looking at on Limelight’s documentation. Its like a foreign language to me.

posts.name: icemannie
posts.cooked: This tutorial is for FTC robots but it serves as a good introduction to the Limelight. What have you done with your Limelight so far?

posts.name: Austin Muse
posts.cooked: We followed the tutorial on the Limelight manual. We calibrated it and setup an Apriltag pipeline. We can get the camera to see the tags and id them successfully. That is as far as we have gotten. We have no idea how to then take that information and actually do something with it.

posts.name: 4391 Programming Mentor
posts.cooked: Every experienced person that’s looked at our code wants to puke, so I may not be the best to listen to but here’s what we did our first year with these and had a similar goal.  Collect the “robot pose in target space” coordinates from the camera.  This contains the X, Y, and rotation (yaw) values of the robots position relative to the tag.  It contains some other stuff too but only those 3 things are what you’re after.  Assuming swerve drive, I’m guessing in your code you have a spot where the robot can be commanded to drive “robot relative” in the X, Y, and Yaw based on joystick inputs.  Can substitute the joystick inputs with calculations.  For example, drive robot relative in the robot’s Y based on the difference of where the proper robot pose in target space value says you are, and the value you find lands you where you want to be.  Same for X and Yaw.  I am no expert, but that’s how we started, and we got good at it.  We’ve since moved on to full time pose estimation, but that I don’t think would have gone well for us if we hadn’t first done this.  I think you have a good goal for this year.  Best of luck hang in there.

posts.name: Austin Muse
posts.cooked: I am watching the video that was shared above and I had no idea that the Limelight hardware did all the stuff that is shared in the video.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Truffle_Shuffle:

aligns the robot either 6 inches to left of the AprilTag on the reef

Truffle_Shuffle:

I know what “pose estimation” is, we aren’t trying all that

These don’t makes sense together to me. Let’s take a vocab-lite approach to describe the problem statement.

You want to go to a certain spot.

Driving to a spot involves telling your drivetrain how to move.

Figuring out how much to move will be calculated from the difference between where you are currently at, and where you want to be.

You’ve stated a definition for “where you want to be”. IE, 6 inches to left of the AprilTag on the reef .

Can you provide a corresponding definition for “where you are currently at?”.

From there, it might be easier to work toward using existing tools to derive your definition of “where you are currently at”.

posts.name: Austin Muse
posts.cooked: When we drive up to the reef and put our bumper against the reef, the limelight sees the tag and knows where we currently are. If we want to align our coral mechanism on the robot to the left branch of the reef, we can hit a button on the driver controller (lets just say it’s the left on the POV) and the robot automatically orients itself the appropriate offset from the apriltag so that the coral mechanism on our robot is aligned with the branches. Last night according to the Limelight Hardware Manager outputs to be aligned with the left branch our robot is tx = +23.38 degrees and ty=+2.60 degrees.

posts.name: icemannie
posts.cooked: Limelight has a feature called Point of Interest. It shifts the TX reading by the number of meters set in. So if you are going for the left or right side you need to do LimelightHelpers.SetFidcuial3DOffset( camera name, xshift, yshift,zshift) xshift would be + or -
